Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Winning personality, heaps of charm?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: My wife is the game player in the family, sir.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Games?  One mistake and I promise you this: I'll make you hate me.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: We are building this railroad across Africa for the glorious purpose of saving Africa from the Africans. And, of course, to end slavery. The Germans and French are our competition. We are ahead, and we will stay ahead providing you do what I hired you to do-

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: -build the bridge over the Tsavo river. And be finished in four months time. Can you do that?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'm sure you've examined my record. So you know I've never yet been late on a bridge.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: You've never built in Africa.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: But I have in India- every country presents problems.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: You'll need your confidence, I promise you.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I've got a reason far beyond confidence: my wife is having our firstborn in five months and I promised I'd be with her when the baby comes.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Very moving, Patterson; I'm touched you confided in me.  -don't make me break you.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Then I've a train to catch.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: I tried to be late, John- it would have been easier if you'd gone.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: We're not much good at goodbyes, Helena.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: Tell me about Beaumont- does he understand how brilliant you are, how lucky he is to have you?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It was embarrassing- the man showered me with compliments.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: Oh dear-  -you're geting that downtrodden look again-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -well, it's just...  ...other men don't abandon their wives at such a time-

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: -oh please- if I'd been against your taking this, you would have abandoned me. You've been desperate to see Africa your whole life.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What if there are complications?-

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: -not "what if"- there will be, there always are. Which only means that our "son" and I- note my confidence- will have an excuse to come visit.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: Go, now.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I am desperate to see Africa- but I hate the leaving.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: You build bridges, John-  -you've got to go where the rivers are.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Nigel Starling- I'll be assisting you at Tsavo- but surely Beaumont must have told you that.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: He just gave me his "monster" speech.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: That. I know Robert seems dreadful, but when you truly get to know the man, well, he's much worse.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Aren't they amazing?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You know the most amazing thing about them?- they only sleep five minutes a day.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Don't much like them.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: The females are bigger- only animal here like that- have to be or they wouldn't survive because the males eat the young.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Anything special about them?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Just that they fart through their mouths.  Must make kissing something of a gamble.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I've lived in Africa a year and I don't know what you know. How long have you been here?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Every time I see something like that, I know we're right to be here- to bring Christianity into their lives, enrich their souls.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Beaumont says it's to end slavery.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: -best I stop. One of the by-products of my belief is that I can become amazingly boring. But I know God smiles on me.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Samuel is camp liaison- absolutely indispensable- the only man here everyone trusts.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Does he speak English?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: And very poor French.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Samuel- John Patterson.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: -we have been getting ready for you.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Excellent. Could I see the bridge site?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I've got medical supplies to deliver. Come along to the hospital when you're done.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I will bring him, Nigel.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Why do the workers look unhappy?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Because they are here.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It's all wonderfully under control, Samuel- you've done a splendid job.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Thank you. The truth is this: you have to work at it constantly.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: The workers don't get on?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Get on? They detest each other. Obviously the Africans hate the Indians. But the Indians also hate the other Indians. Some of them worship cows, while others eat them.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Railhead is across there.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Three thousand men laying track- when the bridge is done, it all joins up.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Did it look like this in your mind?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: This is more difficult-

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Finish your tour?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What is this, mostly malaria?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Yes- but their suffering is only transitory- once they except God into their hearts, He will vanquish all pain.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: That was meant to be charming, sorry. I seem to have lost the knack.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: You never had it.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Nigel and I don't like each other much.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I am also liaison between these two.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Clearly you don't agree about building the railroad?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: This sham? Ridiculous. Who needs it? It's only being built to control the ivory trade, make men richer.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Then why do you stay?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Who else would hire me?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: This is Karim, one of my orderlies- attacked by a man-eater earlier today- first incident of that kind here.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: A man-eater attacks and you're such a buffoon you almost forget to mention it?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Well, he got away, didn't he?  Riding a donkey not far from here when the lion sprang on them- donkey took the brunt of it- then suddenly the lion ran off.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: I know it's your first day and of course you must be tired from the journey-  -but what are you going to do about it?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I couldn't believe it when you said "sort it out." As if it were the most normal thing in the world. "Ho-hum, what lovely tea, I think I'll bag a killer beast this evening, nothing much else going on anyway."

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Well, he put me in a spot, didn't he? But that's all right- after all, I'm responsible for everything that happens here. And it certainly won't do much for morale if a man-eater's on the prowl.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: You said "of course" you'd need the donkey. Why "of course"?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: We know three things about man-eaters. First, they always return to where they've attacked before. Second, they're always old- they can't catch other animals so they turn to us. And third, they're always alone- they've been cast out by their pride because they can't keep up.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I don't suppose I could watch.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Might be exciting for you.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I've never been all that adventurous. I wouldn't be in the way?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'd love the company. And I've hunted all my life.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: The pain is actually quite unbearable now.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Shhh.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I'm sure you mean that to be comforting, but-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -you'll have to deal with it, Nigel.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: That is precisely my plan- but back in my tent.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: They own the night- nobody moves when there's a man-eater out there.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: John? I know this isn't the time to ask, but-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Since you'd only been here three hours when we met, are you sure this is how you hunt lions?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Not to terrify you, Nigel, but it's worse than you think- I've never even seen one.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: ...one shot...

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Patterson has made the nights safe again.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -sufficient supplies on hand?

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: More than.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: With much more on the way-  -John- we could have had this chat on flatter ground-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -true enough- but without the comedy relief.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: How lucky we are.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Aren't we full of ourselves today?  I think it's because of the lion.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Possibly.

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: You know, I too have killed a lion.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: How many shots did you need?

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: I used my hands.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: All right- thee second embankment will go there.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: You do plan to mark it a bit more precisely than just-  -"there."

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: In your honor, Nigel. And you and Singh will be in charge of building them- and you'll also build the roadbeds and the three foundation pillars- and you'll be finished in eight thrilling weeks.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: John, it will not be easy.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Nigel, you'll just have to use your hands-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What are they looking at?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: You- they cannot believe you're still here.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Nonsense.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: You don't know what Tsavo means, do you?  It means "slaughter"...

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: -then he feasted on him, starting with his feet-

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: -please- you needn't be so graphic-

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: You intend "sorting this out" tonight?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'll try- but this feels so different- that old lion I killed could never carry off a man Singh's size.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: But you said they were always old.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: That's what the books say...

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You were contracted to work-

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: -malaria epidemic; very sudden.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Let me see the sick.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: Oh, you're a doctor now, too?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: There is no reason for fear.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: On that I choose to remain dubious.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Second death? Where?-

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: There's even less of him than of Singh.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Samuel?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: We should construct thorn fences around every tent area. Fires burning at night.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Fine. Get started. And a strict curfew- no one allowed out at night.  And I'm sorry for my tone earlier. But I repeat- there is no reason for fear. I will kill the lion and I will build the bridge.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: Of course you will, you are white, you can do anything...

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Not good enough- look, it's got to be tighter. Tighter.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: What a good week.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You mean nobody died?

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I like the blood, is that strange?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Oh yes, I think so.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Look out, Samuel, here it comes.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: Even you two must admit that it is a glorious thing, what Man can accomplish. When there is a common splendid goal, there are no limits. Think what we will accomplish when we all have God's warmth in our hearts.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: I am immune to your disdain.  Now I've decided to move on to something really difficult: I will not rest until both of you are safely in the fold.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I've had four wives, good luck.

Speaker: starling
Dialogue: The struggle is the glory...

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: For you.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Thank you, Samuel.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Good news?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I expect so- it's from my wife.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Do you love her?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I do, actually; very much.

Speaker: helena
Dialogue: That was an attempt at humor but I don't feel very funny these days. I miss you terribly and after our son- I still have total confidence- well, after he's born I think travel might be broadening. As he kicks me at night I'm quite sure he's telling me he definitely wants to come to Africa.  Thought you might need reminding.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Jesus, two of them...

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -there's nothing wrong with your men so stop telling me there is-

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: -you do not call me a liar- you know nothing of their health- consider yourself fortunate I persuaded so many to stay- consider yourself fortunate I have decided to stay-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -Beaumont is on that train- he matters-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: He sees this chaos, he'll replace you all.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: He'll replace you, too- that's all you really care about.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You think so? Fine.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Pleasant journey?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: How could it be? I hate Africa.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Lovely sound- they seem happy.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Don't they, though?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: So work must be going well?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: There has been the occasional odd hiccup- but then, as you so wisely told me, I'd never built in Africa.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: But overall, you're pleased?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I have never experienced anything like it.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: I almost feel like getting right back on.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: I suppose it would be a dereliction of duty not to at least look around.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Morning, friend, glorious day.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: As are they all.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: I do need to see Starling.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Starling?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Awhile back he ordered some bibles-  Is he here?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Yes he is.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Well, I need to speak to him.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Let me deliver the bibles.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Excellent show.  Where is Starling?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Here he comes now.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: What in hell is going on?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: The Ghost and The Darkness have come.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: In English.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It's what the natives are calling the lions-  -two lions have been causing trouble-

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: -what's the surprise in that, this is Africa?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It hasn't been that simple so far.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: What have they done besides kill Starling?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Well, of course, I can't supply a totally accurate answer because there are those that are actually authenticated and there are those that we once thought were workers killing each other or deserting from camp so any number I give is subject to error-

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Thirty, I should think.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: This is supposed to be salvation?  What kind of idiocy are we dealing with here?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'm calling it my "contraption"- we're going to surround it with a boma- a fence, to you- and we're going to leave a small opening opposite that door.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: In that half will be bait- human bait- I'll start things off-  -a sliding door will fit above that and a trip wire will run across the floor.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Genius- the beast will enter, tripping the wire, the door will slide down, trapping him, you, safe behind the bars, will have him at your mercy and will shoot him.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Are you running a high fever, man? How could you expect something as lunatic as this to succeed? How could you even conceive of it?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I didn't conceive of it for the lions- I built one in India when there was trouble with a tiger.

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: And it worked?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: But I'm convinced the theory is sound.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: I made a mistake hiring you- you're simply not up to the job.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You genuinely enjoy trying to terrify people, don't you? Well, fine-  -except there isn't a higher rated engineer and we both know that. And since time is so important to you, how long do you think it would take to find someone else qualified and bring him here?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: Let me explain about time- you've been here three months and already two months behind. And the Germans and the French are gearing up. And I don't care about you and I don't care about the thirty dead- I care about my knighthood and if this railroad finishes on schedule, I'll get my knighthood and I want it.  Professional hunters may be the answer.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: All they'll bring is more chaos and we've plenty of that already- and if they come in, word will get out- and what happens to your knighthood then?

Speaker: beaumont
Dialogue: I'm going to try and locate Redbeard- I assume you've heard of him.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Every man who's ever fired a rifle has heard of him- by the time you find him, the lions will be dead.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Very good indeed.

Speaker: middle coolie
Dialogue: We have hunted since childhood.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: All right- you'll spend your nights inside.  You'll have plenty of ammunition. You're totally protected, you have really nothing to fear.

Speaker: middle coolie
Dialogue: That is correct.  Nothing.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Not once?- you didn't hit it once?-

Speaker: middle coolie
Dialogue: -I would never make excuses- but a fire broke out- the light was bad- he kept moving-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -well, of course he kept moving- but he couldn't have been more than ten feet away from the three of you- surely you must have wounded the thing-

Speaker: middle coolie
Dialogue: I assure you we came close many times-

Speaker: middle coolie
Dialogue: -the next time we will do better.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: The next time will be as this time- The Devil has come to Tsavo-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -that's ridiculous talk and you can't seriously believe it-

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: -now you're telling me my beliefs?- I don't think so-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I wasn't and you know it and don't push it- just listen- we have a problem in Tsavo-

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: -at last you're right- we do- you are the problem in Tsavo-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: -careful, Abdullah-

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: You do not tell me "careful"- you do not tell me anything- you listen while I talk-

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: No hints, Samuel.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: You don't know all that has happened here- the Devil has come to Tsavo.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: You're right. The Devil has come. Look at me. I am the Devil.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: I am a man of peace.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Am I to take it you want to live?

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: Most certainly. Absolutely. Yes.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Excellent decision.  Your name is Abdullah? I'm sure we'll meet again. Go and enjoy the splendid morning.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: I think it's been a pleasure.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I didn't have a chance to thank you.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: What did I do?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Got me out of trouble.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: We need to talk.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Let me save time-  I'm sorrier than you are that I'm here- I hate Tsavo. So I will help you by killing the lions and leaving, and you will help me by doing what I tell you so I can leave. See any problems?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Actually, no.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: All right- let's go into battle.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Somehow I guessed.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Starting now, we attack them.

Speaker: abdullah
Dialogue: How; we don't know where they are?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: We'll have to make them come to us, won't we? And since there are two of them, we're going to set two plans in motion.  First: we must move the entire hospital by tomorrow night.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: That's a terrible idea-

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: -is it, I'm sorry, but then, of course, you're the doctor, you should know.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Silliest thing I ever heard of- why in the world should we go through all that?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: I have been desperate for Patterson to let me move the hospital since the day he arrived.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Soon.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I have to ask- why do you need me?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: I don't really. But understand something- even though it may take me two or three days to sort this out-  -when I'm gone, you'll still have to build the bridge. And I don't want the men to have lost respect for you.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: That's very considerate.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: I'm always considerate- my mother taught me that.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Why do you laugh?- you don't believe she taught me?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I don't believe you had a mother.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You like him, don't you?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Oh yes. But it takes time.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You've known him long?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Since his beard was red.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: How many cattle?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Four should do it.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: They will want a lot of money.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Have you got it?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: No, but you do-  And fifty warriors at the camp before dawn.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Why so many?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Because I have two plans to kill the lions- one involving the cattle, the other the men.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: The Ghost and the Darkness have come... and we can do nothing... but if you anger them... they will stay in Tsavo... and life will become more unberable, that I know...

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You don't enjoy killing, do you?

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Then why do it?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: I have a gift.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: Strange man.  Has he always been this way?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Much gentler now.

Speaker: hawthorne
Dialogue: ...then I will.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Thank you.  Why does he need you by him?

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: He doesn't. He needs nobody. But we have hunted many times...  ...he knows I am afraid of lions...

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: -in there.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: The best way to ensure the kill when you're using trackers is for one to shoot while the other uses the trackers to force the lion toward the shooter. Have you ever led trackers?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I can try.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Samuel says you killed a lion.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: It was probably luck- I'd rather you did the shooting.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: You'd never force the lion to me- and nobody ever got a lion with one shot by luck.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Shoot for chrissakes!-

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Did you ever see a lion that size?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Not even close.  What happened?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: ...misfire... it jammed...

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Has it ever done that before?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: ...don't know...

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: It's Hawthorne's.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: You exchanged weapons?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: They have an expression in prizefighting: "everyone has a plan until they're hit."

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: And stay there.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: And where will you sleep beautifully?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Think about something else.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Have you ever failed?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Goddammit!

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: It's all right. Stay ready.  They know it's there.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Excellent notion- I used the same device myself once.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: But of course yours worked.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: In point of fact it didn't- but I'm convinced the idea is sound.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: You just got hit.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: In my town, when I was little, there was a brute, a bully who terrorized the place.  Alone they were only brutes. Together they became lethal, together they killed.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: What happened to them?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Dear God-

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Their den?  Have you ever seen anything like this?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Nobody's seen anything like this. Lions don't have caves like this-  -they're doing it for pleasure.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: One of my chief attributes is that I'm always calm.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: They're only lions, yes?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Don't they have to be?...

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Both of them over there.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: Ever have to use a machan?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: They're used to people in trees, not in a clearing.  It may be tight.

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Not for me- I'm too bulky and it's your idea, you go up there.  Take the others to the water tower for the night.

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'll be bait alone?

Speaker: redbeard
Dialogue: Yes. And I'll be in some distant tree where I can provide no assistance whatsoever.  Can you control your fear?

Speaker: patterson
Dialogue: I'll have to.
